test-gdpr.question: Which of the following statements about cybersecurity is true?

answers.text: Cybersecurity is about keeping physical information secure.
Cybersecurity is about keeping digital information secure.
Cybersecurity is about keeping physical and digital information secure.

test-gdpr.question: Which of the following is a possible consequence of a cybersecurity threat?

answers.text: We can no longer pay bills.
Employees can no longer contact clients.
Clients, partners, and employees lose trust in the organization.

test-gdpr.question: Why do businesses work hard on their cybersecurity?

answers.text: Because they often cooperate with other companies.
Because a cybersecurity threat can have huge financial consequences.
To conform with the privacy regulations.

test-gdpr.question: Why is cybersecurity important?

answers.text: Because incidents can endanger the health and safety of people.
Because some incidents cannot be solved.
Because this is how you prevent unauthorized access to the office.

test-gdpr.question: How does malware threaten cybersecurity?

answers.text: By damaging or erasing information.
By installing malicious hardware.
By automatically opening attachments in phishing emails.

test-gdpr.question: You use the internet in public. When is this a threat to cybersecurity?

answers.text: When you set up a device as a hotspot.
When you use mobile internet.
When you use a public Wi-Fi network.

test-gdpr.question: Is it safe to store information in a public cloud?

answers.text: Yes, public cloud services are well protected and therefore secure.
No, because some public cloud services are allowed to access your files.
No, because everyone has access to the information in a public cloud.

test-gdpr.question: Why do IoT devices pose a threat to cybersecurity?

answers.text: Because they are easy to hack.
Because they break easily.
Because they tend to lose their connection to the internet.

test-gdpr.question: How do phishers operate?

answers.text: They listen in when you are having a confidential discussion in public.
They send emails in which they ask for personal or business information.
They search wastepaper bins to find personal or business information.

test-gdpr.question: How does the IoT pose a threat to cybersecurity?

answers.text: When different devices do not communicate with each other properly, a data leak occurs.
When you forget your password, it is difficult to access personal information.
When default passwords are not changed, hackers can get easy access to sensitive information.

test-gdpr.question: When do cybercriminals commit spoofing?

answers.text: When they replicate a website.
When they spread malware.
When they break into a public Wi-Fi network.

test-gdpr.question: How can you recognize a phishing email?

answers.text: The sender is not familiar.
The sender cannot be found on the internet.
The sender's name does not match the email address.

test-gdpr.question: Which characteristics of an email suggest the possibility of a phishing attempt?

answers.text: It arrives at night.
It starts with a general greeting.
It doesn't have a subject.

test-gdpr.question: How can you recognize a phishing email?

answers.text: The images are not downloaded automatically.
It has an attachment.
It requests personal information.

test-gdpr.question: Which sentence is a sign of phishing?

answers.text: "Go to our website to see all offers."
"Click on the link, register and win a free iPad."
"Dear Peter, we have a wonderful offer for you!"

test-gdpr.question: How can you protect your IoT devices?

answers.text: By turning off the internet connection whenever it is not needed.
By only connecting the devices with your own Wi-Fi network.
By only connecting the devices with mobile internet.

test-gdpr.question: How can you reduce the risk of infection with malware?

answers.text: By regularly making backups of your programs.
By keeping programs up to date.
By keeping new programs in the downloads folder.

test-gdpr.question: Why should you make regular backups?

answers.text: To secure information in the event of a crash or a malware infection.
To keep information available to all your colleagues.
To keep information available when you are offline.

test-gdpr.question: When does an antivirus program have to be enabled?

answers.text: Only when you suspect a threat.
At least once a day.
Always.

test-gdpr.question: When is your use of the IoT secure?

answers.text: When you use the same strong password for each device.
When you use a different strong password for each device.
When you use the default password for each device, because it is a strong password.

test-gdpr.question: You have a new IoT device. In what way do you change the login information?

answers.text: You change the default username to your email address.
You use the password that is given in the user manual.
You change the default password to a new strong password.

test-gdpr.question: You receive a request via email to send personal information. What is the best thing to do?

answers.text: Check whether the sender is allowed to receive the information.
Do not provide the information and delete the email.
Send the requested information, but also ask for an explanation.

test-gdpr.question: You receive a suspicious email. What should you do?

answers.text: Delete the email and notify your immediate colleagues.
Notify the responsible person or department.
Block the sender and delete the email.

test-gdpr.question: What is a good way to remember your passwords?

answers.text: Write them down in a password logbook.
Keep them in a secured Excel file.
Use a password manager.

test-gdpr.question: What is two-factor authentication?

answers.text: The protection of your login information with two different strong passwords.
The protection of your login information with a strong password and a one-time code, a fingerprint, a hard token, etc.
The protection of your login information with a password in which you have used at least two different types of characters.

test-gdpr.question: What is the most secure way to use the internet in public?

answers.text: Using a secure Wi-Fi network.
Using a public Wi-Fi network.
Using mobile internet.

test-gdpr.question: Why should you use a VPN when using public internet?

answers.text: A VPN stops phishing emails.
A VPN blocks infected ads.
A VPN encrypts all information that you send.

test-gdpr.question: Why should you remove cookies regularly?

answers.text: Cookies follow you around the internet.
Cookies spread malware.
Cookies slow down your internet speed.

test-gdpr.question: Which of the following statements about the privacy settings of social media accounts is true?

answers.text: They can barely be changed, which makes your information visible to everyone.
They are often automatically set to “public”, which makes your information visible to everyone.
They are often automatically set to “private”, which makes your information invisible to strangers.

test-gdpr.question: What is a good practice when using social media?

answers.text: Giving serious thought to posting sensitive information.
Checking your privacy settings before posting sensitive information.
Not posting sensitive information.

test-gdpr.question: What is a good way to protect your online privacy?

answers.text: Using an ad blocker in your browser.
Not using social media at work.
Using an antivirus program.

test-gdpr.question: What is a good step toward making mobile devices criminal-proof?

answers.text: Install the latest software version.
Disable the location features of your device.
Set up a strong password or biometric recognition.
